pages.title: Alloy Forge
pages.text: This chapter is taken from the $(l:https://github.com/LordDeatHunter/Alloy-Forgery/wiki)Alloy Forgery wiki$(/l).

pages.title: Forge Controllers
pages.text: You can currently make an Alloy Forge out of 5 materials: Bricks, Stone Bricks, Blackstone, Deepslate, and End Stone.

pages.name: Forge Construction
pages.text: The visualization placement is currently broken.

pages.title: Forge Controller Recipe
pages.text: The Forge Controller Recipe is crafted from the respective material of the forge tier with a blast furnace in the middle.

pages.title: Tiers and Materials
pages.text: Tiers are important for making recipes harder to make, or to make them more efficient. Currently as of 1.3.0 of Alloy Forgery there are 5 different materials for forges:$(li)Bricks and Stone Bricks, which are used for Tier 1 Alloy Forge.$(li)Deepslate and Blackstone, which are used for Tier 2 Alloy Forge.$(li)Endstone, which is used for a Tier 3 Alloy Forge.

pages.title: Fuels
pages.text: A forge can by default be fueled by vanilla materials. Currently they accept the following list:$(li)Coal and Blocks of Coal$(li)Charcoal$(li)Blaze Rods$(li)Lava Bucket

pages.title: Automation
pages.text: You can use hoppers to automate alloy forging.$(br)  1. Fuel$(br)  2. Ingredients$(br)  3. Outputs$(br2)The controller gives a comparator output, which is very useful for locking the input hopper.

pages.name: Automation Construction

This example shows a Forge made using Deepslate ($(o)glass blocks so you can see the comparator inside the chamber$()). The yellow wool blocks could be anything.$(br2)This setup locks the hopper when once the prescribed number of ores/blocks enter the Forge Controller. Once processed, the hopper is unlocked to receive the next batch.
